Author: snowmaker
Content:
Guys, relax. PG has already told us he's taking the feature out ... should be gone in a few days.

Incidentally, we never wanted iPaper to be implemented how it was on Hacker News. Our recommended implementation is always to give users a choice between iPaper and the original format. We asked PG to change it several times, but he was too busy creating the next 12 Googles, not that I blame him.

JDF President, Scribd

Author: daniel-cussen
Content:
"Melissa Chang of Pure Incubation recently listed five excellent reasons why a recession was a great time to start a company.

"But you don't have to wait for a recession. There has never been a better time to start a company than now..."

Recessions are bad for companies. Not good. Bad. Being 'forced' to 'be leaner' and such through numerous recessionary inconveniences is like environmental coercion.

There's a reason seedlings germinate when spring is coming.

Author: alnayyir
Title: How many of you would use a digital library?
Content:
I mean a true digital library that has non-public works that haven't been expired yet. I've been working out a legal contraption in my mind combined with some locative ideas, and I might have some ideas for working it out. Anyway, this would be an ad supported venture.

I'm not certain how I'd make the media accessible, I definitely don't want a scribd situation, and I want to leave the option of downloading for use on PDAs and other devices.

I guess my question is...should I bother? I came up the idea out of pure frustration in trying to find a Gore Vidal novel I wanted on the internet. Now I'm getting a damn library card tomorrow (today technically).

If you would make use of this, how frequently would you do so?

Author: tel
Content:
I think some part of the Scribd hating of late is that — at least on osx — pdfs are actually pretty enjoyable.

Scribd does a good thing given that they have to operate online through flash, but having pdfs actually be convenient at an OS level trumps that.

I know it's no help for those stuck using Adobe, but it is, from my experience, some part of an explanation.

Author: colinplamondon
Content:
Firefox 3- it's more stable, Del.icio.us integration is better on it, the awesome bar is awesome, and Greasemonkey works with it.

A lot of Greasemonkey plugins are pretty useless, but GoogleAutoPager is fantastic. It makes it so that Google searches are on an infinite page, as you scroll down the plugin gets the next page of results and slots them in so you never have to click next page

http://lifehacker.com/software/google/download-of-the-day-go...

Also, FF3 has Firebug. Game, set, and match.

Author: SwellJoe
Content:
I happen to prefer it. On every computer I use (all of which run some variant of Linux), Acrobat Reader opens in a pop up window, which is annoying and slow. I generally simply avoid all PDF links for this reason, but Scribd links aren't quite as offensive. I'd certainly always prefer my web to be HTML only (with a few pictures of cats), but if you've got to send me to a PDF, it might as well be one that lives in the browser.

I'm not sure why there's been such a backlash against Scribd lately. It's just something you read, you know? Neither PDF nor Scribd is enjoyable to use...so why complain about Scribd? It makes it more convenient and fast for some of us, and doesn't really impact others very much. Just because you happen to find Acrobat Reader slightly less annoying than Scribd (because I know you can't find reading PDFs enjoyable) doesn't mean you should be able to make the experience here at HN less consistent. I know that PDF links at HN will always be reasonably fast and available on my machines without having a new window open. If you could choose to provide a PDF directly, I would no longer click on PDFs, because I would never know whether I was getting the slow and irritating popup window, or the much less slow and mostly non-irritating Scribd interface.

Author: rplevy
Content:
I was about to say "what's the bid deal? there is a download link etc etc" but then I checked and realized these links go right to a view where the flash pdf viewer occupies the whole page. There's no obvious modification of the URL query string to make it show in the view where there is a download link. So if you see a big mangled attempt at loading flash instead of flash for whatever reasons, there's no other option.

This page has an acceptable view where there is a link to download: http://www.scribd.com/doc/3292935/THE-LITTLE-MERMAID

But the automatic scribd links don't show it in this view.

Author: mattthazhmon
Title: Next Gen Code Editor prototype
Content:
About a year ago, I saw a screencast for a next gen code editor. Instead of entering code into a text file, you visually manipulated the states of the variables in the IDE. And as the program executed, the visual showed how the states of the variables would change.

I've been searching for that demo and can't find it. The list of keywords returns too many results and it's not in the top 100.

Does any one remember anything like this? I think it was someone's phd thesis.
